children.subject: What comes to mind are fintech careers, which may perhaps rely more, in a technical manner, on stats along with CS, but Econ is probably a plus in terms of providing you with a good background in high level stuff a fintech engineer or data scientist would be implementing in software or analytics. There are lots of companies who are currently employing lots of engineers to build their trading systems (I will be interning for one, though I don't have any background or interest in econ particularly). I guess with that, it probably isn't that important to know econ. that well for a more technical/software-heavy job; and if you really find a position that requires a deep background in both computing and econ, it's probably something you'd need to do grad. school for anyway. I would do it if you have a great interest in Econ, though! I just wouldn't be too stressed as far as whether it's crucial for getting a CS job in the finance industry anyway. Now, if you would rather be an economist than a programmer, that's a different story...

history.content:
Hi, I'm currently a CS major (sophomore). I'm interested in Econ and seeking to pursue a double major in it. 

I am wondering what new opportunities, if any, are more likely to present themselves as a CS major also studying Econ. I'm not too sure what I want to exactly pursue in industry. Sorry for the vague question.

Thanks!
history.subject: Question on double majoring in CS + Econ
